title: John Lubbock, 2nd Baron Avebury
text:
John Birkbeck Lubbock, 2nd Baron Avebury, (4 October 1858 – 26 March 1929) was a British <a href="aristocracy">aristocrat</a> and <a href="banker">banker</a>.
Background.
He was the eldest son of <a href="John%20Lubbock%2C%201st%20Baron%20Avebury">John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury</a> (1834–1913), and his first wife Ellen Frances Hordern (1841–1879). He succeeded his father as <a href="Baron%20Avebury">Baron Avebury</a> upon his death in 1913. He was born, and died, at the family home, High Elms, in <a href="Farnborough%2C%20Kent">Farnborough, Kent</a>.
He was educated at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>, and then at <a href="Balliol%20College%2C%20Oxford">Balliol College, Oxford</a>, where he graduated as <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">B.A.</a> and <a href="Master%20of%20Arts">M.A.</a> in the same year of 1885.
Career.
Lubbock was a director of the family banking firm, Robbarts, Lubbock and Company, from 1880 until 1914 when it was taken over by <a href="Coutts">Coutts & Co.</a>, where he became a director in turn, and of the British <a href="National%20Provincial%20Bank">National Provincial Bank</a> and a member of the boards of five colonial banks, eight insurance companies and five investment trusts, including the <a href="Bank%20of%20New%20Zealand">Bank of New Zealand</a>, <a href="Lloyd%27s%20of%20London">Lloyd's of London</a>, <a href="Royal%20Exchange%20Assurance">Royal Exchange Assurance Co</a>, Australian Mortgage Land and Finance Co., and Australian Mercantile Land and Finance Co.
In 1925 he chaired the Lubbock Committee looking at repayment of War Savings Certificates.
He was also a <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">Deputy Lieutenant</a> for the county of <a href="Kent">Kent</a>.
Sports.
In his youth, he was a keen sportsman. At school he played both <a href="association%20football">association football</a> and <a href="cricket">cricket</a> although not in their representative XIs, but he won in 1876 a game of <a href="Eton%20Fives">Eton Fives</a> with <a href="Ivo%20Bligh%2C%208th%20Earl%20of%20Darnley">Ivo Bligh</a> who was later famous as the captain of the England cricket team of <a href="The%20Ashes">"Ashes"</a> fame.
At university, he joined the <a href="Oxford%20University%20A.F.C.">Oxford University A.F.C.</a>, playing with them in the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> ties of 1879-80 up to the <a href="1880%20FA%20Cup%20Final">Cup Final</a> at <a href="Kennington%20Oval">Kennington Oval</a> on 10 April 1880 when his team lost 1–0 to <a href="Clapham%20Rovers">Clapham Rovers</a>. He also played against Cambridge University as a football 'Blue' in 1881, and was also a 'Blue' at <a href="real%20tennis">real tennis</a> when he lost in the doubles.
He played cricket for the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">M.C.C.</a>, <a href="I%20Zingari">I Zingari</a> and West Kent, and, later in life, scratch <a href="golf">golf</a>.
Sporting honours.
Oxford University
1880 FA Cup Final (runner-up)
Heir.
Lord Avebury died unmarried in 1929 at the age of seventy and was succeeded in the Barony by his nephew, <a href="John%20Lubbock%2C%203rd%20Baron%20Avebury">John Lubbock</a>.
